title: Androgynous Form of Shiva and Parvati (Ardhanarishvara)

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of gray schist.

credit_line: James W. and Marilynn Alsdorf Collection. Gift of Marilynn Alsdorf
publication_history: Pratapaditya Pal with contributions by Stephen Little, A Collecting Odyssey: Indian, Himalayan, and Southeast Asian Art from the James and Marilynn Alsdorf Collection (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago in association with Thames and Hudson, 1997), 24 (ill.), 275–6, cat. 18. Thomas Eugene, Donaldson, Siva-Pårvatï and Allied Images - Their Iconography and Body Language, 2 vols. (New Delhi: D.K. Printworld (P) Ltd, 2007), 236–237, fig. 174. Gerd J.R. Mevissen, “Corpus of Ardhanarisvara Images from Nepal, Eastern India and Southeast Asia,” Berliner Indologische Studien or Berlin Indological Studies, 21 (2013): 273–298. Gerd J.R. Mevissen, “Images of Ardhanarisvara from Bengal and Nepal: A Chronological Survey,” in South Asian Archaeology and Art: Papers from the 20th conference of the European Association for South Asian Archaeology and Art held in Vienna from 4th to 9th July 2010, Vol 1. (Turnhout, Belgium: Brepols Publishers, 2014), 176. Ulrich Von Schroeder, Nepalese Stone Sculptures, vol. 1. (Weesen, Switzerland: Visual Dharma Publications, 2019), 699–701, pl. 217: 217D, pl. 699.
exhibition_history: Art Institute of Chicago, A Collecting Odyssey: Indian, Himalayan, and Southeast Asian Art from the James and Marilynn Alsdorf Collection, Aug. 2–Oct. 26, 1997, cat. 18.
provenance_text: With Dale Crawford, London, by Mar. 8, 1985 [this and the following according to invoice from Dale Crawford, Mar. 8, 1985; copy in curatorial object file]; sold to James W. Alsdorf (1913–1990) and Marilynn B. Alsdorf (1925–2019), Winnetka and Chicago, IL, Mar. 8, 1985; by descent to Marilynn B. Alsdorf, Chicago, 1990 [on loan to the Art Institute of Chicago, Sept. 17, 1997; publicly promised as a gift to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1997; signed a promised gift agreement for the work, 2002]; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 2021.

input: Androgynous Form of Shiva and Parvati (Ardhanarishvara)
